finding: Twins with the G allele of rs263429, located near GATA3-AS1, reported greater liking for potato chips than those with the other allele, based on multivariate GWAS results with a p-value less than 1x10^-5.
title: Studies of human twins reveal genetic variation that affects dietary fat perception

finding: This SNP, linked to the DNAJC1 gene, associated with several cancers. It represented the most polygenic locus on chromosome 10, reinforcing connections between WM-BAG genetic architecture and cancer traits.
title: The Genetic Architecture of Multimodal Human Brain Age

finding: The SNP rs11200014 in the FGFR2 locus on chromosome 10 was identified as a known susceptibility variant. The analysis showed a significant association with a P-value less than 5.0 x 10^-8, emphasizing its relevance in cancer susceptibility.
title: A mixed-model approach for powerful testing of genetic associations with cancer risk incorporating tumor characteristics

finding: The SNP rs10886471, associated with GRK5, was related to type 2 diabetes (T2D) susceptibility in the Chinese population. Individuals carrying the TT genotype exhibited a resistance to treatment with the insulin secretagogue repaglinide, showing lower reductions in fasting plasma glucose levels compared to those with CC and CT genotypes. This finding indicated that GRK5 plays a crucial role in regulating beta-cell mass and function, linking genetic variations to diabetes susceptibility.
title: Type 2 diabetes susceptibility gene GRK5 regulates physiological pancreatic β-cell proliferation via phosphorylation of HDAC5 in mice

finding: The SNP rs11101422 was associated with the modulation of the mTORC1 pathway, which plays a key role in regulating male germline differentiation. The finding indicated that variations in this SNP could influence the activity of the TOR kinase, thereby impacting stem cell maintenance and differentiation processes in the model organism, Drosophila.
title: mTORC1 is required for differentiation of germline stem cells in the Drosophila melanogaster testis

finding: The SNP rs3824662, located in the GATA3 gene, was identified as an ATAC-QTL associated with the risk of developing B-cell lineage acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL). The analysis demonstrated that this variant influenced chromatin accessibility in both patient samples and ALL patient-derived xenograft (PDX) models.
title: Epigenomic mapping in B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia identifies transcriptional regulators and noncoding variants promoting distinct chromatin architectures

finding: The finding indicated that the inhibition of Pannexin 1 was associated with a reduction in the tumorigenic properties of human melanoma cells, which linked rs11010102 to cancer progression in melanoma.
title: Novel Pannexin 1 isoform is increased in cancer

finding: The SNP rs1890185 was found to reside 398bp upstream of the L1#1 insertion, which is located in a promoter flanking region (ENSR00000032826) expected to regulate the expression of nearby genes. This SNP was significantly associated with schizophrenia, as it was part of an LD block containing 72 SNPs that were linked to 10 diseases or disorders and 28 other traits. In particular, rs1890185 shared strong correlations with other common SNPs, indicating its relevance in the genetic architecture of neuropsychiatric disorders.
title: Machine learning reveals bilateral distribution of somatic L1 insertions in human neurons and glia

finding: The SNP rs11101587 was identified within the context of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), specifically relating to the expression of histone deacetylases. The findings indicated that HDAC7 inhibition altered the transcriptional landscape in cancer cells, suggesting a functional role for this SNP in modulating gene expression linked to cancer phenotypes, particularly influencing stemness and heterochromatin features.
title: Heterochromatin spreading in cancer cells through HDAC7 mediated histone H3.3 landscape reprogramming

finding: The SNP rs11101586 was associated with PTEN Hamartoma Tumor Syndrome (PHTS) and linked to the aberrant adipose tissue growth observed in patients. This context related to the study wherein researchers examined the effects of PTEN levels on adipocyte progenitor cells (APCs) proliferation, differentiation, and senescence. The study noted that PTEN knockdown increased adipogenic potential, which may be influenced by genetic variations such as rs11101586.
title: PTEN regulates adipocyte progenitor growth, differentiation and replicative aging

finding: The SNP rs41298872 within the DCLRE1C locus was identified as significantly associated with J-gene trimming for both productive (P = 1.99 × 10⁻²⁹) and non-productive TCRs (P = 3.18 × 10⁻³⁷), as well as V-gene trimming for non-productive (P = 2.81 × 10⁻²¹) and productive (P = 6.23 × 10⁻²³) TCRs.
title: Combining genotypes and T cell receptor distributions to infer genetic loci determining V(D)J recombination probabilities

finding: This SNP was identified as a secondary independent signal within the DCLRE1C locus specifically associated with J-gene trimming of non-productive TCRs.
title: Combining genotypes and T cell receptor distributions to infer genetic loci determining V(D)J recombination probabilities

finding: The SNP rs2273892 within the DNTT locus was associated with increased N-insertions during V(D)J recombination, specifically correlating to D-J N-insertion events in both productive and non-productive TCRs.
title: Combining genotypes and T cell receptor distributions to infer genetic loci determining V(D)J recombination probabilities

finding: The SNP rs12569756 also within the DNTT locus was significantly associated with D-J N-insertion events for productive and non-productive TCRs, reinforcing its role in N-insertion processes.
title: Combining genotypes and T cell receptor distributions to infer genetic loci determining V(D)J recombination probabilities

finding: The non-synonymous SNP rs12768894, located in the DCLRE1C locus, was confirmed to be significantly associated with both V-gene (productive P = 2.16 × 10⁻¹⁴; non-productive P = 7.21 × 10⁻¹⁴) and J-gene trimming (productive P = 1.23 × 10⁻¹¹; non-productive P = 6.62 × 10⁻¹²) in both discovery and validation cohorts.
title: Combining genotypes and T cell receptor distributions to infer genetic loci determining V(D)J recombination probabilities

finding: The rare variant rs148641196 exhibited the highest allele-specific activity in reporter assays. It restored a functional interferon regulatory factor (IRF) binding site from an ETS binding site, which could promote inflammation-induced dysregulation of the JCAD/SVIL locus during disease progression. In the context of ischemic heart disease (IHD) and heart failure (IHF), both ETS1 and IRF3 expression was upregulated in capillary endothelial cells, linking the variant to inflammation-related mechanisms.
title: Cardiovascular disease causes proinflammatory microvascular changes in the human right atrium

finding: Variant rs9337951 was highlighted as the top candidate associated with ischemic heart disease based on EpiMap analysis, displaying significant effects on enhancer activity. CRISPR mediated deletion of the regulatory elements containing this variant resulted in a 50-70% decrease in JCAD expression, indicating its crucial role in gene regulation related to cardiovascular disease.
title: Cardiovascular disease causes proinflammatory microvascular changes in the human right atrium

finding: The common variant rs1342150 showed allele-specific enhancer activity along with rs9337951. This indicates that it may contribute to regulatory mechanisms in the JCAD/SVIL locus relevant to the pathophysiology of ischemic heart disease, aligning with findings from population studies.
title: Cardiovascular disease causes proinflammatory microvascular changes in the human right atrium

finding: This rare variant was included among those that exhibited significant allele-specific enhancer activity, suggesting its potential involvement in the regulatory network of the JCAD/SVIL locus and its association with ischemic heart disease.
title: Cardiovascular disease causes proinflammatory microvascular changes in the human right atrium

finding: As one of the seven rare variants tested, rs113622617 demonstrated allele-specific enhancer activity, hinting at its potential regulatory function within the JCAD/SVIL locus in context to heart disease.
title: Cardiovascular disease causes proinflammatory microvascular changes in the human right atrium

finding: This rare variant was also found to exhibit allele-specific enhancer activity, supporting the notion that rare SNPs in the JCAD/SVIL locus can modulate gene expression and potentially influence susceptibility to ischemic heart disease.
title: Cardiovascular disease causes proinflammatory microvascular changes in the human right atrium

finding: The ANXA11 rs1049550 variant led to increased sensitivity to chemotherapy in CRC patients, marking it as a significant predictive marker.
title: Pharmacogenomics, biomarker network and allele frequencies in colorectal cancer

finding: This intergenic SNP at 10q24.33 was associated with melanoma and prostate cancer.
title: Pan-Cancer Study Detects Novel Genetic Risk Variants and Shared Genetic Basis in Two Large Cohorts

finding: This SNP was associated with pulse pressure and identified as the index variant previously, showcasing its regulatory capacity in relation to the PRKG1 gene.
title: Fine mapping spatiotemporal mechanisms of genetic variants underlying cardiac traits and disease

finding: The finding determined that rs7068821 (chr10:90051035:G>T) was the most likely candidate causal variant for the T1D-risk signal associated with PTEN and LIPJ expression in adult pancreatic exocrine tissues.
title: Disease-associated regulatory variation often displays plasticity or temporal-specificity in fetal pancreas

finding: The SNP rs61839660 was found to be significantly associated with Type 1 Diabetes (T1D), demonstrating connections through significant looping interactions with the genes IL15RA and RBM17. These interactions were identified in various immune cell types, indicating its potential regulatory role, particularly in adaptive immunity.
title: Loop Catalog: a comprehensive HiChIP database of human and mouse samples

finding: The SNP rs9664184 was identified as a shared eQTL/pQTL exemplifying its significant regulatory role on gene MYOZ1, affecting both transcript and protein levels.
title: Tissue-specific multiOMICs analysis of atrial fibrillation

finding: This SNP, linked to IL2RA, was identified in enhancer regions which could potentially influence Treg function.
title: 3DFAACTS-SNP: Using regulatory T cell-specific epigenomics data to uncover candidate mechanisms of Type-1 Diabetes (T1D) risk

finding: This variant was found to have relevance across autoimmune diseases, linking it to T1D as well.
title: 3DFAACTS-SNP: Using regulatory T cell-specific epigenomics data to uncover candidate mechanisms of Type-1 Diabetes (T1D) risk

finding: This SNP was identified in associations with genes important for glycolytic control in Tregs, suggesting a role in T1D.
title: 3DFAACTS-SNP: Using regulatory T cell-specific epigenomics data to uncover candidate mechanisms of Type-1 Diabetes (T1D) risk

finding: This SNP was also linked to mechanisms governing T1D, acting via shared pathways with other autoimmune conditions.
title: 3DFAACTS-SNP: Using regulatory T cell-specific epigenomics data to uncover candidate mechanisms of Type-1 Diabetes (T1D) risk

finding: Predicted to alter transcription factor binding associated with Treg expression pathways, suggesting contributions to T1D.
title: 3DFAACTS-SNP: Using regulatory T cell-specific epigenomics data to uncover candidate mechanisms of Type-1 Diabetes (T1D) risk

finding: In the analysis of microseminoprotein beta (MSMB) and prostate cancer risk, rs10993994 was confirmed as the lead prostate cancer susceptibility variant, showing a protective role for MSMB. The odds ratio (OR) was 0.758 for prostate cancer per standard deviation change in MSMB levels, with a p-value of 7.81 × 10^-13.
title: Phenome-wide Mendelian randomization mapping the influence of the plasma proteome on complex diseases

finding: Using two conditional independent cis instruments, including rs61847070, the study found an odds ratio (OR) of 0.766 for prostate cancer risk per standard deviation change in MSMB levels, confirming the protective effect of MSMB with a p-value of 4.48 × 10^-14.
title: Phenome-wide Mendelian randomization mapping the influence of the plasma proteome on complex diseases

finding: The SNP rs10993994 located within the MSMB gene on chromosome 10 was associated with prostate cancer. The study identified it as a consistently replicated susceptibility signal.
title: Inverted genomic regions between reference genome builds in humans impact imputation accuracy and decrease the power of association testing

finding: The SNP rs10763546 was assessed for its association with prostate cancer and resulted in marginal evidence of association (OR = 1.11, P<sub>meta</sub> = 0.0011) after meta-analysis across array platforms. However, when corrected using the triple-liftOver method, its imputation accuracy improved, yielding an OR of 1.14 and P = 2.86×10<sup>-7</sup>, which approached genome-wide significance.
title: Inverted genomic regions between reference genome builds in humans impact imputation accuracy and decrease the power of association testing

finding: The SNP rs2981579 in the FGFR2 gene was identified as a component influencing breast cancer risk, highlighted by the new findings in association with previously reported data.
title: DOT: Gene-set analysis by combining decorrelated association statistics

finding: The SNP rs2981427 was discovered as a notable new association with breast cancer risk located within the FGFR2 gene region.
title: DOT: Gene-set analysis by combining decorrelated association statistics

finding: This SNP has been historically linked to breast cancer susceptibility and upheld its significance in the present analysis.
title: DOT: Gene-set analysis by combining decorrelated association statistics

finding: The SNP rs10994278 was identified as an intronic variant within the Ankyrin-3 (ANK3) gene, associated with any psychotic experience. It had an odds ratio (OR) of 1.16 with a p-value of 3.06 x 10^-8, indicating an increased risk of psychotic experiences in individuals carrying this variant.
title: Genetic association study of psychotic experiences in UK Biobank

finding: Linked with multiple sclerosis, this SNP was associated with B cell regulatory elements, influencing T cell-dependent antibody responses.
title: Integrated single-cell transcriptomics and epigenomics reveals strong germinal center-associated etiology of autoimmune risk loci

finding: This SNP exhibited a regulatory potential at the HHEX locus and was linked to multiple sclerosis, revealing its importance in memory B cell decisions.
title: Integrated single-cell transcriptomics and epigenomics reveals strong germinal center-associated etiology of autoimmune risk loci

finding: Part of the autoimmune variant landscape, this SNP was associated with multiple sclerosis, highlighting its role in immune processes.
title: Integrated single-cell transcriptomics and epigenomics reveals strong germinal center-associated etiology of autoimmune risk loci

finding: SNP rs649339, associated with <italic>SYT17</italic>, was also noted for being proximal to a gene that exhibited significant enrichment and specific expression in dopaminergic neurons, indicating its potential implications in the genetics of Parkinson's disease.
title: Single cell spatial transcriptomic and translatomic profiling of dopaminergic neurons in health, aging and disease

finding: The SNP rs11191557 was associated with schizophrenia and was linked to the promoter of the gene INA in neurons, indicating INA as a potential novel target gene for this SNP, supported by evidence from prior eQTL studies.
title: SnapHiC-G: identifying long-range enhancer-promoter interactions from single-cell Hi-C data via a global background model

finding: Similar to rs11191557, the SNP rs11191558 was also connected to the promoter of the gene INA in neurons, reinforcing the association of this gene with schizophrenia risk.
title: SnapHiC-G: identifying long-range enhancer-promoter interactions from single-cell Hi-C data via a global background model

finding: The SNP rs11191559 exhibited a connection to the INA promoter in neurons, further supporting its potential role as a target gene related to schizophrenia.
title: SnapHiC-G: identifying long-range enhancer-promoter interactions from single-cell Hi-C data via a global background model

finding: The SNP rs10883832 was linked to the INA promoter in a neuron-specific manner, suggesting its involvement in the genetic landscape of schizophrenia through this gene.
title: SnapHiC-G: identifying long-range enhancer-promoter interactions from single-cell Hi-C data via a global background model

finding: The SNP rs12413046 was found to interact with the INA promoter in neurons, contributing to the evidence supporting INA as a potential target gene for schizophrenia-associated variants.
title: SnapHiC-G: identifying long-range enhancer-promoter interactions from single-cell Hi-C data via a global background model

finding: The SNP rs118137427, which has a 3.7% allele frequency in Europeans, was associated with expanded repeat sequences at the FRA10B fragile site. This finding linked the SNP to the acquisition of terminal 10q mosaic deletions in normal blood, as analyzed in primary chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL) samples. Specifically, in a cohort from the PCAWG comprising 94 CLLs, rs118137427 was found in 2 out of 4 CLLs (50%) with 10q24.32 deletions, compared to only 6 out of 90 CLLs (6.7%) with intact 10q, yielding a significant p-value of 0.035 in Fisher's exact test. This indicated a potential role for germline genetic variants at FRA10B in influencing somatic structural variants within CLL.
title: Haplotype-aware single-cell multiomics uncovers functional effects of somatic structural variation

finding: The SNP rs10823108, located in the SIRT1 gene, was identified as being responsible for genetic susceptibility to diabetic nephropathy. This finding highlighted its role within metabolic disorders and underlined the impact of genetic variation on the severity of diabetes symptoms.
title: A natural genetic variation screen identifies insulin signaling, neuronal communication, and innate immunity as modifiers of hyperglycemia in the absence of Sirt1

finding: The variant rs2770197 was linked to histological indicators of tissue degradation in subcutaneous adipose tissue, including increased vacuole size and cell membrane deterioration. Pathway enrichment suggested associations with adipogenesis and fatty acid metabolism.
title: HistoGWAS: An AI Framework for Automated and Interpretable Genetic Analysis of Tissue Phenotypes

finding: This variant exhibited allele-specific enhancer activity and restored a functional IRF binding site of an ETS binding site, which could promote inflammatory signaling during disease development. Elevated expression of IRF7 and decreased expression of ETS2 in coronary endothelial cells in ischemic heart disease and ischemic heart failure were noted as important changes associated with this SNP.
title: Single-cell dissection of live human hearts in ischemic heart disease and heart failure reveals cell-type-specific driver genes and pathways

finding: This variant, as part of the JCAD/SVIL locus, was significantly associated with coronary artery disease, and was identified as a top candidate in EpiMap data. It was shown to affect reporter gene expression in human aortic endothelial cells under pro-atherogenic conditions.
title: Single-cell dissection of live human hearts in ischemic heart disease and heart failure reveals cell-type-specific driver genes and pathways

finding: As a common variant within the haplotype studied, this SNP exhibited allele-specific enhancer activity, indicating its role in modifying regulatory processes in cardiovascular cells that could affect disease progression.
title: Single-cell dissection of live human hearts in ischemic heart disease and heart failure reveals cell-type-specific driver genes and pathways

finding: This rare variant was part of a group that displayed allele-specific enhancer activity, indicating it likely plays a role in modulating gene expression relevant to ischemic heart disease.
title: Single-cell dissection of live human hearts in ischemic heart disease and heart failure reveals cell-type-specific driver genes and pathways

finding: Another rare variant among those studied, it exhibited allele-specific enhancer activity and was associated with regulatory changes impacting transcription in the cardiovascular context.
title: Single-cell dissection of live human hearts in ischemic heart disease and heart failure reveals cell-type-specific driver genes and pathways

finding: This SNP, like others in the group of rare variants, showed allele-specific enhancer activity, suggesting its influence on gene regulatory networks in heart-related diseases.
title: Single-cell dissection of live human hearts in ischemic heart disease and heart failure reveals cell-type-specific driver genes and pathways

finding: The SNP rs2274224, which resides in exon 19 of the PLCE1 gene, was found to have a significant association with limbic network-FC, with a p-value of 1.771×10^-10. The high CADD score of 17.35 indicated that this ExNS SNP is likely deleterious and related to cellular processes governed by phospholipase C ε1, further impacting brain function.
title: Specificity and overlap in the genetic architectures of functional and structural connectivity within cerebral resting-state networks

finding: The SNP rs2274223, located in exon 25 of the PLCE1 gene, exhibited a strong association with limbic network-FC with a p-value of 1.22×10^-5. With a CADD score of 17.48, this ExNS SNP was also considered potentially deleterious, highlighting its relevance in the regulatory processes of cell growth and gene expression in relation to brain function.
title: Specificity and overlap in the genetic architectures of functional and structural connectivity within cerebral resting-state networks

finding: The SNP rs72782676 was located in a UNICORN region and had fine-mapping evidence for multiple traits, including eosinophil count, asthma, eczema, respiratory, and ENT diseases. It showed a high posterior inclusion probability (PIP > 0.99 in all GWAS), suggesting a strong association with these traits. The nearest gene, GATA3, is a critical transcriptional regulator for T Helper 2 lineage commitment and is involved in inflammatory diseases.
title: Leveraging Base Pair Mammalian Constraint to Understand Genetic Variation and Human Disease

finding: It was highlighted as a regulatory variant with a high MpraVAE score of 0.683. It was located in the intergenic region of the PPRC1 gene and found in an open chromatin region across five immune cell types, linked by a chromatin loop to the promoter region of NFKB2. This gene is part of the NFkB complex and plays a central role in inflammation and immune response.
title: In silico generation and augmentation of regulatory variants from massively parallel reporter assay using conditional variational autoencoder

finding: The SNP rs61839660, located within the CaRE4 enhancer of the IL2RA gene, was associated with protection against Type 1 Diabetes (T1D). Experimental studies revealed that deletion of the CaRE4 enhancer in NOD mice led to complete protection from autoimmune diabetes, supporting the hypothesis that this variant could modify the risk of autoimmunity. Additionally, the SNP was shown to impair enhancer function and delay IL2RA expression in activated conventional T cells (Tconvs). Thus, despite its subtle impact on gene regulation, the presence or absence of this SNP influenced the dynamics of immune response and the progression of diabetes.
title: T cell subset-selective IL2RA enhancers shape autoimmune diabetes risk

finding: The SNP rs7916587 (G->A) was identified as a top-ranked Grad-CAM SNP for SP1 binding and was associated with white blood cell count (WBC). It disrupted a RUNX binding site near the transcription start site of the gene ARHGAP15, which is known to negatively regulate neutrophil function in mice, indicating its potential relevance to immune response traits.
title: Deep neural networks identify context-specific determinants of transcription factor binding affinity

finding: At the TCF7L2 locus, the SNP rs7903146 was found to increase islet expression of TCF7L2 significantly, indicating its role in T2D development.
title: Influence of genetic variants on gene expression in human pancreatic islets – implications for type 2 diabetes

finding: The <italic>cis</italic>-pQTL rs2995310 was significantly associated with ADAM8 protein levels.
title: Genetic determinants of plasma protein levels in the Estonian population

finding: The SNP rs17095355 was associated with biliary atresia (BA) in a study that included Thai children. The research indicated a polymorphism in the gene X-prolyl aminopeptidase 1, suggesting that specific genetic variations could be linked to the risk of developing BA.
title: Exome Sequencing in Individuals with Isolated Biliary Atresia

finding: The SNP rs41298872 located in the Artemis gene was previously identified as being strongly associated with increased V- and J-gene trimming. Analysis showed that several model coefficients related to local sequence context and nucleotide trimming probabilities varied significantly based on the SNP genotype. Specifically, the negative effect of A nucleotides on trimming odds was reduced in the presence of rs41298872, indicating that individuals carrying this SNP may have less dependence on motif structure and more on the overall openness of the sequence around the trimming site.
title: Statistical inference reveals the role of length, breathing, and nucleotide identity in V(D)J nucleotide trimming

finding: Variant rs1902660 was analyzed as an eQTL and was linked to a higher expression of TSPAN14, which was putatively causal for Alzheimer's Disease (AD), another neurodegenerative disorder.
title: EMO: Predicting Non-coding Mutation-induced Up- and Down-regulation of Risk Gene Expression using Deep Learning

finding: The SNP rs11191419 was linked to the eGene AS3MT, involved in arsenic metabolism, and its dysregulation may impact various neurodevelopmental pathways relevant to ASD.
title: Autism spectrum disorder: understanding the impact of SNPs on biological pathways in the fetal and adult cortex

finding: Associated with the eGene AS3MT, rs7085104 was determined to affect signaling processes that could be significant in the context of ASD.
title: Autism spectrum disorder: understanding the impact of SNPs on biological pathways in the fetal and adult cortex

finding: The rs363371 allele was associated with a lower risk of developing Parkinson's disease in an Italian population. This finding was replicated in a Chinese Han population study specifically for males, supporting the protective effect of the VMAT2 overexpression associated with this SNP.
title: Tricyclic and tetracyclic antidepressants upregulate VMAT2 activity and rescue disease-causing VMAT2 variants

finding: The rs363324 allele was initially reported to be associated with a lower risk of developing Parkinson's disease in an Italian population; however, this finding was not replicated in the studies involving the Chinese Han population.
title: Tricyclic and tetracyclic antidepressants upregulate VMAT2 activity and rescue disease-causing VMAT2 variants

finding: The SNP rs7906104 was included in the findings from the AUD GWAS, being one of the identified significant loci linked to the AUD diagnosis.
title: Genome-wide Association Study of Alcohol Consumption and Use Disorder in Multiple Populations (N = 274,424)

finding: The SNP rs41298373 was significantly associated with planum temporale asymmetry at chromosome 10p14 (P = 3.31x10^-17). The findings were further validated through sensitivity analyses and highlighted its relation to a coding polymorphism within exon 9 of the ITIH5 gene. It was associated with multiple brain morphology measures including left-right brain asymmetry, sulcal depth, cortical surface area, and cortical thickness, showcasing its role in genetically controlled brain lateralization.
title: Using rare genetic mutations to revisit structural brain asymmetry

finding: The SNP rs1334909357, located within an intron of the PALD1 gene, was positively associated with BMI in children from Salvador, where African ancestry was high.
title: Admixture/fine-mapping in Brazilians reveals a West African associated potential regulatory variant (rs114066381) with a strong female-specific effect on body mass- and fat mass-indexes

finding: The linked SNP rs79947827, located in the ZMIZ1 gene, was associated with BMI in children from Salvador, indicating the influence of African ancestry on this phenotype.
title: Admixture/fine-mapping in Brazilians reveals a West African associated potential regulatory variant (rs114066381) with a strong female-specific effect on body mass- and fat mass-indexes

finding: The SNP rs141274185, also linked with rs79947827 in the ZMIZ1 gene, was found to be positively associated with BMI in the Salvador children cohort.
title: Admixture/fine-mapping in Brazilians reveals a West African associated potential regulatory variant (rs114066381) with a strong female-specific effect on body mass- and fat mass-indexes

finding: The N999S variant (rs886039469) was associated with gain-of-function properties in BK channels, leading to increased BK currents and action potential firing in transgenic mice. It was shown to significantly influence the pathophysiology of paroxysmal non-kinesigenic dyskinesia (PNKD3), evidenced by the stress-induced immobility episodes observed in Kcnma1N999S/WT mice, indicating its pathogenic potential.
title: BK channel properties correlate with neurobehavioral severity in three KCNMA1-linked channelopathy mouse models

finding: The D434G variant (rs137853333) was also found to exhibit gain-of-function characteristics in BK channels and contributed to increased seizure propensity in transgenic mice. Similar to the N999S variant, it exhibited notable effects on BK currents and action potential firing, establishing its relevance in the clinical heterogeneity observed in PNKD3.
title: BK channel properties correlate with neurobehavioral severity in three KCNMA1-linked channelopathy mouse models

finding: The SNP rs4539242 was identified as one of the top QTL associations for the metabolite N2-acetyl,N6,N6-dimethyllysine and also for N6-methyllysine, indicating its role in regulating these specific metabolites.
title: yQTL Pipeline: a structured computational workflow for large scale quantitative trait loci discovery and downstream visualization

finding: The SNP rs768854100 was noted as the top QTL for undecanedioate on chromosome 10, suggesting a strong association with this specific metabolite.
title: yQTL Pipeline: a structured computational workflow for large scale quantitative trait loci discovery and downstream visualization

finding: The SNP rs11101539 was associated with the modulation of gene transcription relevant to breast cancer cell proliferation and DNA repair, as co-regulated by PARP1 and EP300-BRG1. This finding had significance in understanding the genetic underpinnings of breast cancer, highlighting its role in the specific pathways pertinent to disease biology.
title: Epiregulon: Inference of single-cell transcription factor activity to dissect mechanisms of lineage plasticity and drug response

finding: This SNP, located in the KNDC1 gene and tested in the Allada cohort, replicated in association studies.
title: First genome-wide association study of non-severe malaria in two birth cohorts in Benin

finding: This SNP was centered in a regional plot near the SORCS3 gene on chromosome 10, which presented as the most significantly associated gene for depression (p = 2.27 x 10^-19).
title: Genome-wide meta-analysis of depression identifies 102 independent variants and highlights the importance of the prefrontal brain regions

finding: The SNP rs1799853 was identified as a core single nucleotide variant for the CYP2C9 *2 allele in Neanderthal individuals. This variant was predicted to cause an intermediate metabolizer phenotype in modern humans, resulting in slower metabolism of various drugs. It had a global frequency of less than 5%, with higher frequencies in European and admixed American populations (8-15%). This allele was associated with decreased enzyme activity affecting the metabolism of medications such as warfarin and increasing the risk of adverse drug reactions.
title: Pharmacogenetic variation in Neanderthals and Denisovans and implications for human health and response to medications

finding: The SNP rs41291556 defined the CYP2C19 *8 allele, which was found in Neanderthal individuals and conferred a poor metabolizer status in modern humans. This variant was detected at low frequencies (0.5-1.5%) in a few modern human populations, reflecting significant implications for drug metabolism and efficacy.
title: Pharmacogenetic variation in Neanderthals and Denisovans and implications for human health and response to medications

finding: As a primary sentinel variant for the OBFC1 locus, rs9420907 was associated with telomere length and further analyzed for its role across multiple tissues.
title: Novel genetic determinants of telomere length from a trans-ethnic analysis of 109,122 whole genome sequences in TOPMed

finding: This tertiary signal related to OBFC1 further supports the involvement of this locus in telomere biology, showing evidence of colocalization with eQTLs in skeletal muscle specifically.
title: Novel genetic determinants of telomere length from a trans-ethnic analysis of 109,122 whole genome sequences in TOPMed

finding: Identified as a quaternary signal at the OBFC1 locus, rs10883948 showed association with telomere maintenance and regulatory elements in blood tissues.
title: Novel genetic determinants of telomere length from a trans-ethnic analysis of 109,122 whole genome sequences in TOPMed

finding: The rs4919510 SNP, situated within the miR-608 gene itself, resulted in carriers of the minor allele showing diminished levels of miR-608. This reduction led to limited regulatory control over AChE and other targets, contributing to a protective effect against sepsis following head injury.
title: Ribosomal protein L24 modulates mammalian microRNA processing and transfer RNA fragment production

finding: The SNP rs2986017, associated with the non-synonymous polymorphism p.P86L in the CALHM1 gene, was reported to increase the risk of Alzheimer's Disease (AD) and was linked to effects on calcium homeostasis and amyloid beta accumulation. This finding highlighted its significance in the Alzheimer dementia linkage region on chromosome 10.
title: eMIND: Enabling automatic collection of protein variation impacts in Alzheimer’s disease from the literature

finding: The SNP rs11101244 was associated with agronomic traits in bread wheat under rainfed conditions. It contributed to the understanding of genetic control related to drought tolerance, as identified in marker–trait associations (MTAs) from the GWAS analysis.
title: Identification of QTL hotspots affecting agronomic traits and high-throughput vegetation indices in rainfed wheat

finding: The rs553668 variant of ADRA2A was found to be associated with type 2 diabetes and obesity traits in a population-based study in Mexico City.
title: The Identification of Key Genes and Biological Pathways in Polycystic Ovary Syndrome and its Complications by Next Generation Squancing (NGS) and Bioinformatics Analysis

finding: The SNP rs2102369 was identified as a positive and original finding in the context of predicting above-ground biomass (AGB) in soybean. The study showcased that multi-spectral imaging could enhance the prediction accuracy of genotypic values of AGB by using vegetation indices calculated from early to late growth stages.
title: Time-series Multi-spectral Imaging in Soybean for Improving Biomass and Genomic Prediction Accuracy

finding: The SNP rs12354611 was replicated as related to the microbial signal of Bacteroides stercoris, with a significant association observed (p = 8.64 × 10⁻⁶), reinforcing its relevance among previously reported microbial signals.
title: Mendelian randomization analyses support causal relationships between blood metabolites and the gut microbiome

finding: The tumoral A genotype of the MGMT rs34180180 SNP was associated with shorter survival in patients with aggressive gliomas. This finding highlighted the genetic influence on prognosis in glioma cases and linked the SNP to clinical outcomes.
title: Most of the deregulated CpG-island-controlled genes in glioma do not show DNA methylation defects

finding: The allele A of the lead variant rs2770197 in subcutaneous adipose tissue was linked to increased vacuole size and cell membrane deterioration, indicating tissue degradation. Gene enrichment analysis revealed pathways tied to adipogenesis and metabolism, marking its significance in obesity-related mechanisms.
title: HistoGWAS: An AI Framework for Automated and Interpretable Genetic Analysis of Tissue Phenotypes

finding: The SNP rs1983890 in the PFKFB3 gene was associated with interactions with the anti-apoptotic gene MAIP1 and AGAP1 in the context of type-2 diabetes (T2D). This finding highlighted the epistatic relationship that contributed to the prolonged survival of dysfunctional 'loser' beta-cells, despite the global stress response in T2D. Specifically, the interaction was significant with adjusted p-values of 0.0113 for MAIP1 and 0.0275 for AGAP1, indicating that rs1983890 plays a critical role in the genetic mechanisms underlying beta-cell dysfunction and survival in diabetes.
title: Dysfunctional β-cell longevity in diabetes relies on energy conservation and positive epistasis

finding: The minor allele of rs706779 was associated with protective effects for autoimmune thyroid disease (ATD) when analyzed in the context of other selected SNPs. It was identified through stepwise search as significant, suggesting its role as a possible causal variant in the disease.
title: Sharing information between related diseases using Bayesian joint fine mapping increases accuracy and identifies novel associations in six immune mediated diseases

finding: This SNP tagged a causal variant affecting the expression of IL2RA mRNA and its protein CD25 in CD4+ memory T cells, showing opposite effects in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) compared to T1D, multiple sclerosis (MS), ATD, and juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA). Its identification in multiple disease contexts supports its relevance across diverse autoimmune disorders.
title: Sharing information between related diseases using Bayesian joint fine mapping increases accuracy and identifies novel associations in six immune mediated diseases

finding: Considered a joint tag for distinct variants associated with multiple sclerosis (MS), showing a strong probabilistic model fit and confirming its relevance in autoimmune disease pathogenesis.
title: Sharing information between related diseases using Bayesian joint fine mapping increases accuracy and identifies novel associations in six immune mediated diseases

finding: The T2D-risk allele at rs7903146 was associated with reduced TCF7L2 expression in abdominal adipose progenitor (AP) cells. Specifically, the T allele reduced the mRNA and protein levels of TCF7L2 in these cells compared to the ancestral C allele. This reduction in TCF7L2 expression correlated with enhanced adipose tissue insulin sensitivity among carriers of the T allele. In functional assays, the presence of the T allele abolished enhancer activity of a genomic sequence centered around rs7903146, indicating a cis-regulatory effect on TCF7L2 expression. These findings established that genetic variation at rs7903146 not only influences pancreatic insulin secretion but may also affect T2D risk through modulation of adipose progenitor biology.
title: TCF7L2 plays a complex role in human adipose progenitor biology which may contribute to genetic susceptibility to type 2 diabetes

finding: The variant rs61839660 in the IL2RA gene was linked to type 1 diabetes and other autoimmune disorders. The study defined a functional effect of this T risk allele in primary human CD4 T cells, indicating that it regulates IL2RA and CD25 expression in a context-dependent manner. This finding supported the notion that the disease association at this locus could be influenced by this allele.
title: Defining the function of disease variants with CRISPR editing and multimodal single cell sequencing

finding: Identified with a p-value of 7.0 x 10^-9, SNP rs12762089 was classified as a significant locus associated with schizophrenia through the multitrait GWAS analysis. It was also not recognized in the univariate MRI GWAS, which had a minimum p-value of 2.8 x 10^-4, suggesting it plays a previously overlooked role in the genetics of schizophrenia.
title: Linking the genetic structure of neuroanatomical phenotypes with psychiatric disorders

finding: The SNP rs1334909357, located in the intron of the PALD1 gene, was identified in children from Salvador showing a negative association with BMI, demonstrating the genetic diversity of BMI associations across different population cohorts.
title: Admixture/fine-mapping in Brazilians reveals a West African associated potential regulatory variant (rs114066381) with a strong female-specific effect on body mass- and fat mass-indexes

finding: This SNP, linked to rs141274185, was significant in relation to BMI associations in Salvador, highlighting the role of African ancestry-related genetic variants in influencing BMI.
title: Admixture/fine-mapping in Brazilians reveals a West African associated potential regulatory variant (rs114066381) with a strong female-specific effect on body mass- and fat mass-indexes

finding: Linked SNP rs141274185 was found to be significant in the context of BMI associations in conjunction with rs79947827, further supporting the influence of African ancestry on BMI through these genetic variants.
title: Admixture/fine-mapping in Brazilians reveals a West African associated potential regulatory variant (rs114066381) with a strong female-specific effect on body mass- and fat mass-indexes

finding: The rs11003125 SNP, located in the promoter region of the MBL2 gene, showed a significantly higher frequency of the LL genotype associated with low MBL production in the Russian population (37%) compared to the Nenets (10%) and Dolgan-Nganasans (15%). This difference was statistically significant (p<0.001).
title: Mannose-binding lectin gene polymorphisms in the East Siberia and Russian Arctic populations

finding: The rs5030737 SNP, a part of the combined rare O allele, was found to have a significantly higher homozygous presence in Russians (10%) compared to Nenets (2%) and Dolgan-Nganasans (1%), with a p-value of <0.001.
title: Mannose-binding lectin gene polymorphisms in the East Siberia and Russian Arctic populations

finding: The rs1800450 SNP, included in the collective O allele designation, also exhibited a significantly higher homozygous occurrence in Russians (10%) relative to Nenets (2%) and Dolgan-Nganasans (1%), statistically significant with p<0.001.
title: Mannose-binding lectin gene polymorphisms in the East Siberia and Russian Arctic populations

finding: The SNP rs61846889 was shown to significantly affect gene expression as an eQTL for OGDHL, with an allelic change leading to increased binding for the transcription factor complex, supporting the hypothesis that CpG SNPs influence gene expression via methylation.
title: Cell-type-specific meQTL extends melanoma GWAS annotation beyond eQTL and informs melanocyte gene regulatory mechanisms

finding: The SNP rs11191352 was reported with a significant association to the SmokingInitiation trait (P_SmokingInitiation = 2.12 x 10^-7). It contributed to addiction-associated traits, particularly in differentiated cell types by overlapping with NeuN+ open chromatin regions.
title: Addiction-associated genetic variants implicate brain cell type- and region-specific cis-regulatory elements in addiction neurobiology

finding: The rs363371 allele was linked to VMAT2 overexpression and associated with a lower risk of developing Parkinson's disease in an Italian population. This finding was further supported by replication in the Chinese Han population for males.
title: Tricyclic and tetracyclic antidepressants upregulate VMAT2 activity and rescue disease-causing VMAT2 variants

finding: The rs363324 allele was similarly found to be linked to VMAT2 overexpression and associated with a lower risk of developing Parkinson's disease, although it did not replicate in the Chinese Han population like rs363371.
title: Tricyclic and tetracyclic antidepressants upregulate VMAT2 activity and rescue disease-causing VMAT2 variants

finding: The SNP rs2227551 was associated with Chronic Recurrent Dermatitis (CRD) and was identified as part of the shared core genetic risk factors linking multiple autoimmune diseases (AiDs) including its relation to the immune response.
title: Unravelling the shared genetic mechanisms underlying 18 autoimmune diseases using a systems approach

finding: The SNP rs2227564 was identified alongside rs2227551 in association with Chronic Recurrent Dermatitis (CRD) and contributed to the understanding of genetic overlap in autoimmune conditions.
title: Unravelling the shared genetic mechanisms underlying 18 autoimmune diseases using a systems approach

finding: The SNP rs2688608 was associated with Multiple Sclerosis (MS) and was noted for its shared genetic implications with other AiDs, contributing to the core biological processes linked to polyautoimmunity.
title: Unravelling the shared genetic mechanisms underlying 18 autoimmune diseases using a systems approach

finding: The SNP rs2675662 was linked to Psoriasis (PSO) and was recognized alongside other shared SNPs for its role in the genetic landscape of autoimmune diseases.
title: Unravelling the shared genetic mechanisms underlying 18 autoimmune diseases using a systems approach

finding: The rs17094222 loci in the HIF1AN gene was illustrated as BMI-associated in a Genome-Wide Association Study, highlighting its potential role in body mass regulation. This finding pointed to the involvement of HIF1A in adipocyte differentiation and thermogenesis, indicating its relevance in obesity research.
title: Regulatory Modules of Human Thermogenic Adipocytes: Functional Genomics of Meta-Analyses Derived Marker-Genes

finding: The SNP rs11101449 was associated with increased plasmatic levels of psa-expressing exosomes, which were found to be effective in distinguishing prostate cancer patients from those with benign prostatic hyperplasia. This study, published in 2019 by Logozzi et al., highlighted the diagnostic utility of exosomes in prostate cancer, suggesting that genetic variations like rs11101449 may play a role in the pathology or detection of this cancer type.
title: Tetraspanin immunocapture phenotypes extracellular vesicles according to biofluid source but may limit identification of multiplexed cancer biomarkers

finding: Lead SNP rs2274224, found in the exonic region of PLCCE1:PLCE1-AS1 on chromosome 10, was associated with increased interhemispheric connectivity in minor allele carriers (C, MAF = 0.44) compared to non-carriers. This SNP was identified as one of the lead findings related to hemispheric differences.
title: Imaging genetics of language network functional connectivity reveals links with language-related abilities, dyslexia and handedness

finding: The SNP rs4919685 was significantly associated with testosterone levels, showing a strong statistical association (p=4.203e-15). It was located in the TSS-distal regions linked to the gene Cyp17a1, an enzyme involved in the conversion of testosterone to estradiol.
title: The single-cell epigenetic regulatory landscape in mammalian perinatal testis development

finding: The SNP rs743572 also demonstrated a positive association with testosterone levels (p=3.622e-07), as it was situated in the promoter region of Cyp17a1, further emphasizing its functional relevance in testosterone metabolism.
title: The single-cell epigenetic regulatory landscape in mammalian perinatal testis development

finding: The SNP rs3011351 was associated with cellular mechanisms of activity, drug resistance, and its induced side effects, specifically concerning the efficacy of cisplatin as an anti-tumor drug as discussed in the 2011 study by Florea and Büsselberg.
title: Study on the mechanism of action of the Pt(IV) complex with lonidamine ligands by ultrafast chemical proteomics

finding: This SNP was found to overlap between the genu and anterior body of the corpus callosum, associated with the SHTN1 (or KIAA1598) gene, involved in positive regulation of neuron migration.
title: The Genetic Architecture of the Human Corpus Callosum and its Subregions

finding: Showing strong association with splenium area, this SNP demonstrated a beta coefficient of -1.69 and an exceptionally significant p-value of 2.02 × 10−24, being linked to the FAM53B gene.
title: The Genetic Architecture of the Human Corpus Callosum and its Subregions

finding: Associated with FAM53B gene, this SNP showed a significant association with thickness of the splenium, indicated by a beta coefficient of -0.11 and a p-value of 6.28 × 10−22.
title: The Genetic Architecture of the Human Corpus Callosum and its Subregions

finding: The rs145580445 variant in the UPF2 gene was found to be significantly associated with an increased risk of type 2 diabetes, as indicated by genome-wide association studies (GWAS). This association highlighted the importance of UPF2 in mediating Nonsense-Mediated RNA Decay (NMD) activity and its implications for insulin secretion and cell viability in pancreatic beta cells, particularly in response to proinflammatory cytokines.
title: Proinflammatory Cytokines Suppress Nonsense-Mediated RNA Decay to Impair Regulated Transcript Isoform Processing in Pancreatic β-Cells

finding: The SNP rs11101423 was associated with the regulation of EGFR signals in mammary epithelial cells (MECs). It was found to impact cellular responses during Puberty through modulation of Rasgrp1, influencing EGF-induced proliferation and ductal tree maturation.
title: Fine-tuning of Epithelial EGFR signals Supports Coordinated Mammary Gland Development

finding: This SNP associated with breast, prostate, ovarian, and endometrial cancers, reinforcing its importance as a common genetic factor in cancer susceptibility.
title: Combining genome-wide studies of breast, prostate, ovarian and endometrial cancers maps cross-cancer susceptibility loci and identifies new genetic associations

finding: The lead variant rs370974631 was significantly associated with age-related macular degeneration (AMD) at the ARMS2/HTRA1 locus, showing very strong association evidence with P_GC=3.1×10^-20 and an effect allele frequency (EAF) of 0.23.
title: Chances and challenges of machine learning based disease classification in genetic association studies illustrated on age-related macular degeneration

finding: The SNP rs1041298 was found to be associated with traits relevant to leaf area index (LAI) measurements. This association was based on the study by Pekin and Macfarlane (2009) that demonstrated the impact of crown cover and leaf area index measurements using digital cover photography in the context of remote sensing applications. The findings indicated its significance in effectively measuring canopy attributes in temperate deciduous forests.
title: hemispheR: an R package for fisheye canopy image analysis

finding: The SNP rs3750846 was identified as the sentinel SNP at the 10q26 locus, which is one of the strongest loci linked to AMD risk. It was found to be proximal to a region of accessibility within the intron of the ARMS2 locus, which has been proposed to act as a distal regulatory element. The area contained two distinct peaks of accessibility, shared between rod and cone photoreceptor cells, and enriched in horizontal cells of the human retina. Although the specific role of this locus in relation to MacTel and AMD remained unclear, these findings suggested its importance for further investigations.
title: Multi-omic Analysis of Developing Human Retina and Organoids Reveals Cell-Specific Cis-Regulatory Elements and Mechanisms of Non-Coding Genetic Disease Risk

finding: The SNP rs11101618 demonstrated significant implications in the MAPK signaling pathways, highlighting its role as a promising therapeutic target in cancers including pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors.
title: Digital spatial profiling of RNA in pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors highlights the distinct profile of α-SMA positive stroma and its impact on surrounding tumor cells

finding: The SNP rs2019 was associated with the elasticity of the plant cell wall, which correlated significantly with the instantaneous growth rate of the plants studied. This finding emerged from research that utilized microfluidic devices to assess individual plant growth under controlled conditions. The results highlighted a framework where genetic factors like rs2019 influence the mechanical properties of plant tissues, thereby impacting overall morphogenesis.
title: Assessing the link between tissue elasticity and plant growth

finding: The SNP rs11010102 was linked to the inhibition of Pannexin 1, which significantly reduced the tumorigenic properties of human melanoma cells. This SNP's association with PANX1 provided insight into its potential in developing strategies for enhancing anti-tumor immunity through immune cell infiltration.
title: Global Pannexin 1-deletion increases tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes in the BRAF/Pten mouse melanoma model

finding: The analysis of SNP rs11101596 showed a positive original finding connecting to the identification of Celastrol as a YAP-TEAD inhibitor for cancer therapy.
title: Structure-based discovery of a novel small-molecule inhibitor of TEAD palmitoylation with anticancer activity

finding: The SNP rs11101422 was identified as having a significant association with the regulation of autophagy through the mTORC1 pathway. The research explored its role in various types of cancer, emphasizing the importance of mTORC1 in managing autophagic processes.
title: AutophagyNet: High-resolution data source for the analysis of autophagy and its regulation

finding: The SNP rs1335540 was found to be a lead variant within the context of transcription factor (TF) IKZF1 regulation of the eQTL for the gene APBB1IP. This eQTL was active in 31 GTEx tissues and was found to colocalize with GWAS signals associated with four blood cell traits, indicating that genetic variation at this locus may influence blood cell phenotype through modulation of APBB1IP expression. The variant was located 15 bases upstream of the APBB1IP transcription start site and was shown to overlap an IKZF1 ChIP-seq peak, which supports the hypothesis that IKZF1 acts as a TF regulated by this SNP.
title: Transcription factor regulation of eQTL activity across individuals and tissues

finding: rs7087063 was associated with HMM estimated activity variability during wake with a p-value of 3.0×10^-8 and was located in the gene CELF2, which was previously linked to Alzheimer's disease.
title: Automated Feature Extraction from Population Wearable Device Data Identified Novel Loci Associated with Sleep and Circadian Rhythms

finding: The study identified rs763236375 as a splice-associated variant within the GATA3 gene, which was found in 20 breast cancer samples. This specific 2 bp deletion led to alternative donor site usage for exon 5 of GATA3, resulting in a frameshifted protein product lacking a crucial DNA binding domain. This event was noted to be tumor-specific and correlated with breast cancer, where GATA3 is mutated in approximately 10-15% of cases, indicating its potential role as a driver mutation in tumorigenesis.
title: RegTools: Integrated analysis of genomic and transcriptomic data for the discovery of splice-associated variants in cancer

finding: The SNP rs11190140 was positively associated with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). This association indicated that the variant altered the binding of NFAT, which is relevant to immune regulation and inflammation, potentially linking it to mechanisms involved in the disturbances observed in conditions like ankylosing spondylitis (AS).
title: Deficiencies of Runx3 and tissue-resident CD4+ intestinal epithelial lymphocytes link intestinal dysbiosis and inflammation in mouse and human spondyloarthropathy

finding: IL2RA rs2104286 was associated with multiple sclerosis onset and severity in the research published by Stefanovic et al. in 2020.
title: Identification of biomarkers and pathways for focal segmental glomerulosclerosis using next generation sequencing data and bioinformatics analysis

finding: This SNP was associated with multiple cancers including breast, prostate, and endometrial cancers, correlating strongly with clinical implications in gynecologic disorders.
title: Combining genome-wide studies of breast, prostate, ovarian and endometrial cancers maps cross-cancer susceptibility loci and identifies new genetic associations

finding: SNP rs932658 showed significant interaction with the POE of SIRT1, particularly for the CpG site cg18035618. The data indicated that as part of the genetic modifier effect, this SNP interaction was significant in altering methylation contrasts.
title: Lifestyle and Genetic Factors Modify Parent-of-Origin Effects on the Human Methylome

finding: With a MAF of 0.5, it served as one of the more common alleles in the studied population.
title: The forensic landscape and the population genetic analyses of Hainan Li based on massively parallel sequencing DNA profiling

finding: The variant rs4348791 was associated with the SLC39A12 gene, revealing associations in the caudate, putamen, and pallidum, which are crucial for neurological development.
title: Phenotypic and genetic associations of quantitative magnetic susceptibility in UK Biobank brain imaging

finding: The variant rs11012783 was associated with the CACNB2 gene and revealed spatially contiguous associations in the caudate and putamen, linked to calcium channel function.
title: Phenotypic and genetic associations of quantitative magnetic susceptibility in UK Biobank brain imaging

finding: The SNP rs1412444 in the LIPA locus was associated with increased risk of myocardial infarction (MI) and higher LIPA expression, although the relationship displayed counterintuitive results in homozygous minor individuals.
title: Interpreting coronary artery disease GWAS results: A functional genomics approach assessing biological significance

finding: The SNP rs1051338 was highlighted as a significant eQTL influencing LIPA gene expression in blood, supporting the presence of multiple regulatory variants within the locus.
title: Interpreting coronary artery disease GWAS results: A functional genomics approach assessing biological significance

finding: The SNP rs2250781 also acted as a significant eQTL for LIPA expression, indicating its role as a functional variant.
title: Interpreting coronary artery disease GWAS results: A functional genomics approach assessing biological significance

finding: The SNP rs11203042 was reaffirmed as an eQTL associated with the LIPA locus in the context of GWAS.
title: Interpreting coronary artery disease GWAS results: A functional genomics approach assessing biological significance

finding: The SNP rs12413409 was involved in the expression of multiple genes including CYP17A1, indicating complex regulatory networks.
title: Interpreting coronary artery disease GWAS results: A functional genomics approach assessing biological significance

finding: The SNP rs11191416 was associated with multiple gene expressions within a gene cluster, supporting its role in gene regulation.
title: Interpreting coronary artery disease GWAS results: A functional genomics approach assessing biological significance

finding: The SNP rs11101586 was associated with the regulation of adipocyte progenitor cells (APCs) in the context of PTEN, a known tumor suppressor. The original findings indicated that mutations affecting PTEN levels, potentially linked to rs11101586, influenced the proliferation and differentiation of APCs, contributing to aberrant adipose tissue growth in patients with PTEN Hamartoma Tumor Syndrome (PHTS). This highlighted the role of PTEN in mediating cellular senescence, with decreased levels of the senescence marker CDKN1A (p21) in PTEN knockdown cells.
title: PTEN regulates adipocyte progenitor growth, differentiation and cellular aging

finding: During the study, rs2435357 was examined as a positive control for enhancer activity within enhancer hs737. The research revealed that the enhancer variant rs2435357 exhibited strong enhancer activity when tested in the neuronal cell lines Neuro2a, demonstrating that it plays a significant role in modulating gene expression compared to the reference allele and the promoter-only construct.
title: De Novo Mutation in an Enhancer of EBF3 in simplex autism

finding: This SNP reached significance in a transethnic GWAS before being implicated in NHWs, showcasing the concordance in direction of effect.
title: How understudied populations have contributed to our understanding of Alzheimer’s disease genetics

finding: This loss-of-function variant reduced the risk of AD specifically among APOE E4 homozygotes, marking its potential significance in genetic risk modulation.
title: How understudied populations have contributed to our understanding of Alzheimer’s disease genetics

finding: Reported significant association with familial late onset Alzheimer's disease within European ancestry.
title: How understudied populations have contributed to our understanding of Alzheimer’s disease genetics

finding: The rs7085104 SNP at the 10q24.32 locus was associated with altered expression of the AS3MT gene, which was implicated in schizophrenia (SCZ). This finding constituted a significant contribution to understanding the genetic underpinnings of SCZ.
title: Decoding the multimorbidities among psychiatric disorders and cognitive functioning

finding: The rs1264670 SNP (NC_000004.11:g.146402927G>A) contributed to the formation of a Z-RNA stem in the SMAD1 gene, affecting alternative splicing and expression levels.
title: Z-Flipon Variants reveal the many roles of Z-DNA and Z-RNA in health and disease

finding: The SNP rs10748818 was associated with the NFKB2 gene located at the GBF1 locus and was determined through rare coding variant analyses to be putatively causal in Parkinson's disease risk.
title: Expanding Parkinson’s disease genetics: novel risk loci, genomic context, causal insights and heritable risk

finding: The PFKP rs2388595 SNP was significantly associated with increased lactate levels and decreased hypoxanthine levels across all ancestries, with the association being strongest in Caucasian and Asian donors. It influenced the abundances of several glycolytic metabolites and was shown to impact protein expression, thus playing a critical role in glycolysis in stored RBCs.
title: Biological and Genetic Determinants of Glycolysis: Phosphofructokinase Isoforms Boost Energy Status of Stored Red Blood Cells and Transfusion Outcomes

finding: The SNP rs61839660 was associated with hay fever and/or eczema, demonstrating a larger effect in both hay fever/eczema-only and hay fever/eczema with asthma, compared to asthma-only.
title: Genome-wide association analysis of 350,000 Caucasians from the UK Biobank identifies novel loci for asthma, hay fever and eczema

finding: The SNP rs12722547 was associated with asthma and exhibited a trend indicating a larger effect in asthma-only compared to hay fever/eczema-only.
title: Genome-wide association analysis of 350,000 Caucasians from the UK Biobank identifies novel loci for asthma, hay fever and eczema

finding: Similar to rs3064355, the SNP rs5787309 also exhibited significant departure from HWE (p < 0.0009), suggesting underlying genetic factors affecting its distribution.
title: Genomic history and forensic characteristics of Sherpa highlanders on the Tibetan Plateau inferred from high-resolution genome-wide InDels and SNPs

finding: For rs10761785, both the MVA-significance test and the MC-based correlation replication showed consistent pleiotropic associations across different samples, with a 95% confidence interval for the consistency of effect sizes suggesting strong multi-trait associations, highlighting its relevance to multiple anthropometric traits.
title: Beyond power: Multivariate discovery, replication, and interpretation of pleiotropic loci using summary association statistics

finding: The variant rs117119468 (C->T) completely abolished enhancer function within the IL2RA locus, affecting enhancer activity in both Jurkat T cells and HL60 cells. This finding demonstrated the significant role of this genetic variant in altering non-coding regulatory functions associated with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA).
title: The Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA) Susceptibility Locus, IL2RA, Includes An Intronic Enhancer That Is Attenuated By JIA-Associated Genetic Variants

finding: The variant rs12722502 (C->T) reduced enhancer function by 30% in Jurkat T cells but had no effect in HL60 cells. This finding illustrated the differential impact of specific variants on enhancer activity, further emphasizing the complexity of JIA genetic risk factors.
title: The Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA) Susceptibility Locus, IL2RA, Includes An Intronic Enhancer That Is Attenuated By JIA-Associated Genetic Variants

finding: SNP rs11257655 was associated with type 2 diabetes and located in the CDC123 regulatory region. It exhibited ASB involving FOXA1, ESR1, and three other transcription factors (SPI1, STAT1, and SMC3). FOXA1's involvement in liver and pancreas development and glucose homeostasis linked the SNP with type 2 diabetes and fasting plasma glucose levels.
title: Landscape of allele-specific transcription factor binding in the human genome

finding: For SNP rs7903146 at the TCF7L2 locus, it was identified as a regulatory variant that affects enhancer activities and was also associated with an increased risk for T2D.
title: Deep learning models predict regulatory variants in pancreatic islets and refine type 2 diabetes association signals

finding: The allele rs80194531, which causes an Asn78Thr substitution in the ZEB1 gene and is pathogenic for corneal dystrophy, was dated to be 5,866 generations old (approximately 120,000 to 180,000 years). This ancient age was inconsistent with its reported pathogenic effects, and the allele's frequency was found to be low, suggesting that many variants within similar frequency ranges are comparatively younger.
title: Dating genomic variants and shared ancestry in population-scale sequencing data

finding: The SNP rs11101422 was associated with the regulation of host microRNA expression, particularly miR-126, which played a protective role against Mycobacterium marinum infection in zebrafish. Notably, it was found that this SNP influenced the signaling axes involving tsc1a and cxcl12a, impacting the immune response. The study noted that the upregulation associated with tsc1a rendered zebrafish embryos more susceptible to bacterial burdens and cell death, indicating a significant role for this SNP in the host's immune response mechanisms during infection.
title: Infection-induced miR-126 suppresses tsc1- and cxcl12a-dependent permissive macrophages during mycobacterial infection

finding: The SNP rs2435357, located in intron 1 of the RET gene, was identified as a common variant that significantly affected SOX10 binding to a RET enhancer. It explained 10-20 times of the phenotypic variance compared to rare RET variants and was associated with short-segment Hirschsprung disease (S-HSCR). The risk allele T decreased the expression of RET in enteric neuronal progenitors, contributing to HSCR pathogenesis.
title: Whole-genome analysis of noncoding genetic variations identifies multigranular regulatory element perturbations associated with Hirschsprung disease

finding: The SNP rs10826797, associated with IBD, colocalized with both an actQTL and eQTL for MAP3K8, where it increased acetylation at H3K27 and upregulated MAP3K8 expression, implicating its role in Treg pathway regulation.
title: Immune disease variants modulate gene expression in regulatory CD4+ T cells and inform drug targets

finding: This SNP overlapping an actQTL peak, was part of a colocalization with IBD and regulated MAP3K8, influencing the expression and potential Treg functionality.
title: Immune disease variants modulate gene expression in regulatory CD4+ T cells and inform drug targets

finding: The SNP rs1046747 held a PVS score of 0.543, categorizing it as L3 for medium to high pleiotropy. It was linked to several phenotypes including asthma, leukemia, lymphoma, lymphopenia, and cardiovascular system disease.
title: Pleiotropic Variability Score: A Genome Interpretation Metric to Quantify Phenomic Associations of Genomic Variants

finding: The lead SNP rs17731, located within an exon of KLF6, similarly indicated influence on schizophrenia with a case-control effect size that had not yet achieved significance, suggesting a novel association requiring further investigation.
title: Identifying loci with different allele frequencies among cases of eight psychiatric disorders using CC-GWAS

finding: The rs12779790 polymorphism in the CDC123/CAMK1D gene was associated with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) in women, indicating its relevance in understanding the genetic contributions to GDM.
title: Genome-Wide Polygenic Risk Scores and Prediction of Gestational Diabetes in South Asian Women

finding: The study found a colocalization of the miRNA eQTL for hsa-miR-1307-5p with an mRNA sQTL for splice variants in the 5’ UTR of ATP5MK. The G allele of rs7911488 was linked to increased utilization of splice site variants SpliceA and SpliceD, while concurrently leading to decreased expression of miR-1307-5p.
title: MicroRNA-eQTLs in the developing human neocortex link miR-4707-3p expression to brain size

finding: Associated with psoriasis through strong LD, disrupting several JUNB/AP1 binding motifs vital for regulatory pathways in immune responses.
title: Allele-specific DNA methylation is increased in cancers and its dense mapping in normal plus neoplastic cells increases the yield of disease-associated regulatory SNPs

finding: This SNP indicated links to inflammatory bowel disease, showcasing its role in disease regulation through disrupted motifs.
title: Allele-specific DNA methylation is increased in cancers and its dense mapping in normal plus neoplastic cells increases the yield of disease-associated regulatory SNPs

finding: In strong LD with rs2664280, associated with Type 2 diabetes, altering TF binding sites crucial for metabolic traits.
title: Allele-specific DNA methylation is increased in cancers and its dense mapping in normal plus neoplastic cells increases the yield of disease-associated regulatory SNPs

finding: This SNP disrupted ELF1 motifs related to breast cancer susceptibility, marking it as a critical regulatory variant.
title: Allele-specific DNA methylation is increased in cancers and its dense mapping in normal plus neoplastic cells increases the yield of disease-associated regulatory SNPs

finding: Linked with GWAS data for breast cancer, highlighting its role in hormone-related malignancies.
title: Allele-specific DNA methylation is increased in cancers and its dense mapping in normal plus neoplastic cells increases the yield of disease-associated regulatory SNPs

finding: This synonymous variant in <italic>CPEB3</italic> was identified as an eQTL controlling gene expression in cerebellar regions and associated with cognitive functioning.
title: Exome-wide analysis reveals role of LRP1 and additional novel loci in cognition

finding: Demonstrated contacts with TSPAN14, which has connections to immune pathways, suggesting a link to Alzheimer's pathology.
title: S-BEAM: A Semi-Supervised Ensemble Approach to Rank Potential Causal Variants and Their Target Genes in Microglia for Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: This SNP was the most significant finding with a p-value of 4.75×10−38. The minor allele was associated with a leftward shift of surface area asymmetry for two lateral temporal regions and a rightward shift for two medial temporal regions, as well as a leftward shift of cortical thickness asymmetry in the inferior temporal gyrus.
title: The genetic architecture of structural left-right asymmetry of the human brain

finding: The N999S variant (rs886039469) exhibited gain-of-function properties in BK channels, leading to increased BK currents and action potential firing in transgenic mice. This variant was linked to severe paroxysmal non-kinesigenic dyskinesia (PNKD3) phenotypes, where affected mice demonstrated immobility after stress, a behavior similar to stress-induced immobility episodes observed in patients.
title: BK channel properties correlate with neurobehavioral severity in three KCNMA1-linked channelopathy mouse models

finding: The D434G variant (rs137853333) also displayed gain-of-function characteristics in BK channels and led to increased seizure propensity in transgenic mice, thereby associating it with the paroxysmal non-kinesigenic dyskinesia (PNKD3) phenotype. Like the N999S variant, this mutation contributed to increased BK currents and action potential firing in mice.
title: BK channel properties correlate with neurobehavioral severity in three KCNMA1-linked channelopathy mouse models

finding: The SNP rs1800450 in the Mannose binding lectin gene 2 was linked to the development and severity of COVID-19 infection, contributing to the understanding of genetic risk factors in COVID-19.
title: Comprehensive analysis of next-generation sequencing data in COVID-19 and its secondary complications

finding: The rs12777823 SNP in CYP2C9 was associated with decreased warfarin dose requirement specifically in African Americans (AAs). This finding highlighted the importance of minority-focused studies in uncovering significant genetic associations relevant to drug metabolism in these populations.
title: Uncovering the role of admixture in disease and drug response: Association of hepatocyte gene expression and DNA methylation with African Ancestry in African Americans

finding: SNP rs5030938 at 10q22 was reported in the Peruvian cohort as having the highest overall AdaptMix score, with an AdaptMix P-value of 3.79×10^-15, indicating selection in Native Americans, linked to HKDC1 expression in glucose metabolism.
title: Disentangling signatures of selection before and after European colonization in Latin Americans

finding: SNP rs196262 was characterized as a candidate in the analysis of cooking time, identified through differential expression patterns correlated with cooking time variations.
title: Detecting the genetic variants associated with key culinary traits in Dioscorea alata

finding: SNP rs363258 was similarly indicated as a candidate associated with cooking time, based on differential expression in specific genotypes.
title: Detecting the genetic variants associated with key culinary traits in Dioscorea alata

finding: SNP rs1949352 was noted as a candidate gene influencing dry matter content in relation to differentially expressed genes.
title: Detecting the genetic variants associated with key culinary traits in Dioscorea alata

finding: The SNP rs11192209 was linked to quantitative phenotyping for northern leaf blight using UAV images, as detailed in a 2019 study. This finding suggested that rs11192209 could serve as a genetic marker relevant to the susceptibility of maize to this particular disease, showcasing its utility in disease management and breeding strategies.
title: Global Genotype by Environment Prediction Competition Reveals That Diverse Modeling Strategies Can Deliver Satisfactory Maize Yield Estimates

finding: The SNP rs61863020 was associated with a lower prevalence of insomnia at baseline (OR 0.63 [0.52, 0.75], P-value = 4.74E-8). It served as an eQTL for <italic>ADRA2A</italic> and appeared to support the relationship between this gene and sleep disturbances.
title: Genome-wide association study of Parkinson’s disease progression biomarkers in 12 longitudinal patients’ cohorts

finding: The non-reference alleles for rs12769205 were required to annotate the CYP2C19 *2 star allele, detailed in the study's comparison between biospecimen NA19122 and the GeT-RM NGS consensus.
title: Star allele search: a pharmacogenetic annotation database and user-friendly search tool of publicly available 1000 Genomes Project biospecimens

finding: The non-reference alleles for rs4244285 were required to annotate the CYP2C19 *2 star allele, consistent with the haplotype findings for NA19122 against the GeT-RM NGS consensus.
title: Star allele search: a pharmacogenetic annotation database and user-friendly search tool of publicly available 1000 Genomes Project biospecimens

finding: The presence of non-reference alleles for rs3758581 was crucial for the annotation of the CYP2C19 *2 star allele and was found in biospecimen NA19122.
title: Star allele search: a pharmacogenetic annotation database and user-friendly search tool of publicly available 1000 Genomes Project biospecimens

finding: The non-reference allele at rs17882687 precluded an unambiguous call of CYP2C19 *35 or *15 for biospecimen NA19122 as identified through the annotation process.
title: Star allele search: a pharmacogenetic annotation database and user-friendly search tool of publicly available 1000 Genomes Project biospecimens

finding: The absence of rs9332131 in certain samples led to misannotations; it is critical for the definition of CYP2C9 *6 star allele as highlighted in the discrepancies for samples NA19143 and NA19213.
title: Star allele search: a pharmacogenetic annotation database and user-friendly search tool of publicly available 1000 Genomes Project biospecimens

finding: The rs1799853 variant was part of the requirement for annotating CYP2C9 *61 in the context of sample HG01190 as identified in the study.
title: Star allele search: a pharmacogenetic annotation database and user-friendly search tool of publicly available 1000 Genomes Project biospecimens

finding: Non-reference allele for rs202201137 was required for annotating CYP2C9 *61, and its presence in HG01190 contributed to the observed discrepancies with GeT-RM.
title: Star allele search: a pharmacogenetic annotation database and user-friendly search tool of publicly available 1000 Genomes Project biospecimens

finding: SNP rs12354611 demonstrated significant association with Bacteroides stercoris, achieving a p-value of 8.64 x 10^-6, validating its role in gut microbiome studies.
