title: Inter-determination of blood metabolite levels and gut microbiome supported by Mendelian randomization

finding: This SNP demonstrated a significant association with tumor grade (P=2.87×10⁻⁴).
title: Common breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: Associated with risk of ER-positive disease (P=4.39×10⁻²).
title: Common breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: This SNP was solely associated with HER2 status (P=2.60×10⁻²).
title: Common breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: Strongly associated with risk of all luminal-like subtypes (P=2.01×10⁻²³).
title: Common breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: Associated with risk of luminal-like subtypes (P=5.00×10⁻³⁰).
title: Common breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: Showed associations with ER (P=9.09×10⁻⁷) and grade (P=2.56×10⁻³).
title: Common breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: It was reported that hypomethylated binding sites for transcription factor 7-like 2 (TCF7L2) were linked to increased developmental neurotoxicity and type 2 diabetes (T2D) risk. The T allele of TCF7L2 rs7903146 was also mentioned as being associated with decreased glucose tolerance, highlighting its role in glucose metabolism which aligns with T2D risk.
title: Epigenetic biomarkers of autoimmune risk and protective antioxidant signaling in methylmercury-exposed adults

finding: The SNP rs3740053 located in the promoter of the SIRT1 gene was associated with myocardial infarction (MI) in a study involving 1,227 tag SNPs across 356 Mexican Americans. This particular SNP impeded oxidative stress-induced CTCF regulation of SIRT1 induction, where HEK293 cells homozygous for the -92G MI risk allele did not exhibit H2O2-induced activation of SIRT1, contrasting with the wild-type cells. Furthermore, luciferase reporter assays showed that the wild-type promoter was activated following oxidative stress, but the -92A→G variant was not. This indicates that rs3740053 plays a critical role in modulating gene expression related to oxidative stress response and cardiovascular health.
title: Recruitment of CTCF to the SIRT1 promoter after Oxidative Stress mediates Cardioprotective Transcription

finding: The SNP rs1799853 was identified as the causative missense variant for the CYP2C9*2 allele and had an allele frequency of 8-15% in European and admixed American populations.
title: Archaic introgression and variation in pharmacogenes and implications for local adaptation

finding: The SNP rs41291556 was identified as the causative exonic missense SNP for CYP2C19*8 allele, found at frequencies of 1.5% in Central Europeans and 0.5% in the Telugu population.
title: Archaic introgression and variation in pharmacogenes and implications for local adaptation

finding: The TCF7L2 polymorphism rs7903146 was associated with an increased risk of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), as established by a meta-analysis that indicated its relevance in T2DM pathogenesis.
title: Bioinformatics analysis of potential key genes and mechanisms in type 2 diabetes mellitus

finding: The SDF-1β polymorphism rs1801157 was identified to be significantly associated with T2DM risk, pointing to its potential role in the disease's genetic underpinnings.
title: Bioinformatics analysis of potential key genes and mechanisms in type 2 diabetes mellitus

finding: The rs747334 variant was also predicted to decrease binding affinity but showed an increase in binding affinity upon validation, demonstrating altered interactions with NKX2-5.
title: Disease-Associated Non-Coding Variants Alter NKX2-5 DNA-Binding Affinity

finding: The SNP rs3740053, located in the promoter region of the SIRT1 gene, was associated with myocardial infarction (MI). In a systematic study conducted on 356 healthy Mexican Americans, it was found that this SNP impeded oxidative stress-induced regulation of SIRT1, as HEK293 cells carrying the -92A>G mutation exhibited reduced activation of SIRT1 following H2O2 treatment compared to controls. This suggests that the presence of the -92G allele negatively affected the transcriptional activation of SIRT1 under stress conditions.
title: Recruitment of CTCF to the SIRT1 promoter after Oxidative Stress mediates Cardioprotective Transcription

finding: Identified previously for its effects on islet chromatin accessibility, rs7903146 was confirmed through MPRA to significantly alter transcriptional activity in beta cells.
title: Functional characterization of thousands of type 2 diabetes-associated and chromatin-modulating variants under steady state and endoplasmic reticulum stress

finding: The SNP rs12254441 was associated with body mass index (BMI) and was mapped to the gene <italic>KAT6B</italic> in the GWAS catalog. However, it was identified as an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) targeting <italic>VDAC2</italic> in subcutaneous adipose tissue according to the GTEx project. This finding suggested that rs12254441 might serve as a genetic link between <italic>VDAC2</italic> and BMI rather than <italic>KAT6B</italic>.
title: A Transcriptomic and Proteomic Atlas of Obesity and Type 2 Diabetes in Cynomolgus Monkeys

finding: The SNP rs7903146 was identified in the context of its modifying effects on the relationship between metabolites related to purine catabolism and the risk of type 2 diabetes incidence. This finding suggested that the presence of this polymorphism may influence metabolic outcomes and contribute to diabetes pathophysiology.
title: Functional Characterization of the Lin28/let-7 Circuit during Forelimb Regeneration in Ambystoma mexicanum and its Influence on Metabolic Reprogramming

finding: The missense mutation in MTPAP (rs1047991) was found to replicate its association with RNA methylation levels at position 13710 in the mt-ND5 transcript, linking it to mitochondrial mRNA stability.
title: Nuclear genetic regulation of human mitochondrial RNA modification

finding: The SNP rs2274224 was noted for its associations with body composition measurements, including fat mass.
title: Brain aging comprises many modes of structural and functional change with distinct genetic and biophysical associations

finding: SNP rs4497325 was linked to an associated mode with significant relevance for various health conditions.
title: Brain aging comprises many modes of structural and functional change with distinct genetic and biophysical associations

finding: This SNP was an eQTL of INPP5A, associated with DNA methylation impacts relevant to aging.
title: Brain aging comprises many modes of structural and functional change with distinct genetic and biophysical associations

finding: The rs13500 'T' allele and haplotypes in the CH25H promoter were significantly associated with the risk of developing Alzheimer's disease (AD) and correlated with varying rates of Aβ/amyloid deposition, as shown in a large AlzGene meta-analysis that included 1,282 AD patients and 1,312 controls from five different populations. Although subsequent studies failed to replicate this association, a study conducted in a Turkish cohort confirmed a strong association between CH25H rs13500 and AD, particularly highlighting its elevated risk in individuals carrying the APOE4 allele.
title: 25-Hydroxycholesterol amplifies microglial IL-1β production in an apoE isoform-dependent manner

finding: The variant rs17476364 in HK1 was confirmed as associated with HbA1c, primarily found in European and Hispanic populations, linking it to erythrocyte biology affecting HbA1c assessment.
title: Impact of rare and common genetic variants on diabetes diagnosis by hemoglobin A1c in multi-ancestry cohorts: The Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine Program

finding: The rs10823343 variant was reaffirmed as part of the HK1 association with HbA1c. This variant plays a role in erythrocytic pathways influencing HbA1c measurements in several ancestral groups.
title: Impact of rare and common genetic variants on diabetes diagnosis by hemoglobin A1c in multi-ancestry cohorts: The Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine Program

finding: The SNP rs4745982 was also confirmed as associated with HbA1c in relation to HK1, underlining its importance in understanding the glycemic and non-glycemic pathways impacting HbA1c levels.
title: Impact of rare and common genetic variants on diabetes diagnosis by hemoglobin A1c in multi-ancestry cohorts: The Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine Program

finding: The SNP rs11010068 showed a significant association with targeted delivery mechanisms in tumor therapies. In a study referenced by Kutova et al. (2019), this SNP was linked to improved treatment efficiency through its role in enhancing molecular targeting strategies. This suggested that individuals with certain alleles at this locus might demonstrate different responses to therapies aimed at tumor cells, potentially leading to better therapeutic outcomes in the context of vascular permeability and tumor imaging.
title: Decorrelation Time Mapping as an Analysis Tool for Nanobubble-Based Contrast Enhanced Ultrasound Imaging

finding: The SNP rs145580445 in the UPF2 gene was found to be significantly associated with an increased risk of type 2 diabetes. The investigation involved examining UPF2 deficiency's effect on the viability and insulin secretion of beta-cells, with the purpose of understanding its role in Nonsense-Mediated Decay (NMD) activation. In studies using EndoC-βH3 cells, the knockdown of UPF2 led to a profound reduction in NMD activity, along with a slight but significant prevention of cytokine-induced cell death, although it did not influence glucose-stimulated insulin secretion (GSIS). However, the silencing of UPF2 did significantly increase insulin content, emphasizing the regulatory role of this SNP in beta-cell function under inflammatory conditions.
title: Proinflammatory Cytokines, but not Glucolipotoxicity, Suppress Nonsense-Mediated RNA Decay to Impair Regulated Transcript Isoform Processing in Pancreatic β-Cells

finding: The SNP rs17745507, located in the ADAM12 gene, was implicated in the activity level of the GATA4 transcription factor in cardiomyocytes. This finding suggested a novel association between GATA4 and cardiac hypertrophy mediated through ADAM12, highlighting the potential role of this SNP in cardiac development and function.
title: Monopogen: single nucleotide variant calling from single cell sequencing

finding: The rs2981579 variant mapped to the transcription start site of FGFR2 and formed interaction peaks with several distal fragments. These regions were co-localized with multiple key regulatory elements in breast cancer, explaining the association of this SNP with FGFR2 gene regulation.
title: Exploring the effects of genetic variation on gene regulation in cancer in the context of 3D genome structure

finding: The rs4752575 SNP was strongly associated with breast cancer, affecting the expression of FGFR2 through interactions with a binding site for FOXA1, a crucial regulator in cancer development.
title: Exploring the effects of genetic variation on gene regulation in cancer in the context of 3D genome structure

finding: The SNP rs2789313, located on chromosome 10 and within the MALRD1 gene, was identified as a genome-wide significant variant associated with early age at onset (AAO) major depressive disorder (MDD) with a Z-score of 5.56 and P-value of 2.74 × 10^-8. This gene had not previously been linked to depression, indicating a novel association between this locus and the trait of early onset MDD.
title: Genetic comorbidity between major depression and cardio-metabolic disease, stratified by age at onset of major depression

finding: The SNP rs11010101 was linked to a subclass of non-canonical WNT responsive genes that correlated with poor prognosis in breast cancer. This finding was part of the study by Monteleone et al. (2019), which investigated the functional synergy between SP1 and STAT3, contributing to the understanding of the genetic basis underlying breast cancer aggressiveness and highlighting potential targeting strategies for treatment.
title: Network analysis allows to unravel breast cancer molecular features and to identify novel targets

finding: The SNP was identified as newly FDR significant through Flexible cFDR, leveraging functional genomic data.
title: Leveraging auxiliary data from arbitrary distributions to boost GWAS discovery with Flexible cFDR

finding: The SNP rs1412444 was identified as a lead SNP in CAD associated with increased LIPA expression and enzyme activity specifically in monocytes and macrophages. Risk alleles in rs1412444 enhanced PU.1 binding to an intronic enhancer region, amplifying its regulatory effect on LIPA, which is implicated in exacerbating atherosclerosis.
title: Decoding the variant-to-function relationship for LIPA, a risk locus for coronary artery disease

finding: The SNP rs1320496 was characterized as having the strongest eQTL signal for LIPA in HMDM and foamy macrophages, linking it to enhancer activity that regulates LIPA expression in a monocyte-specific manner.
title: Decoding the variant-to-function relationship for LIPA, a risk locus for coronary artery disease

finding: The rs2246833 SNP, in high linkage disequilibrium with rs1412444, showed associations with higher LIPA mRNA and enzyme activity in human monocytes, supporting its role in CAD risk through regulatory effects on LIPA.
title: Decoding the variant-to-function relationship for LIPA, a risk locus for coronary artery disease

finding: The SNP rs1412445, being in high LD with rs1412444, exhibited contributions to eQTL and CAD risk through its association with LIPA expression, establishing it as an important regulatory variant in the locus.
title: Decoding the variant-to-function relationship for LIPA, a risk locus for coronary artery disease

finding: The SNP rs7903146 at the TCF7L2 locus was classified as having shared effects with TOA scores of 0.31 in islet and 0.37 in adipose tissue, being one of the strongest common variant associations with T2D in Europeans.
title: A multi-omic integrative scheme characterizes tissues of action at loci associated with type 2 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs7918400 was identified as a drive signal at TCF7L2 assigned solely to liver in the latest mapping analysis.
title: A multi-omic integrative scheme characterizes tissues of action at loci associated with type 2 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs140242150 was classified as a primary signal at TCF7L2 with indications of liver-centric mechanisms of action.
title: A multi-omic integrative scheme characterizes tissues of action at loci associated with type 2 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs34872471 exhibited high linkage disequilibrium with rs7903146 and strong enhancer activity in adipose, involved in shared mechanisms at the TCF7L2 locus.
title: A multi-omic integrative scheme characterizes tissues of action at loci associated with type 2 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs11257655 was classified as an islet signal at the CDC123-CAMK1D locus, with PPA=1.0, linking it to CAMK1D expression regulation.
title: A multi-omic integrative scheme characterizes tissues of action at loci associated with type 2 diabetes

finding: This variant was found to be correlated (r²=0.73) with rs35054928 and showed strong association specifically with risk for luminal-like subtypes, but not with triple-negative (TN) subtypes.
title: Common variants in breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: Like rs2981578, this variant also displayed the strongest association with luminal-like subtypes and showed no association with TN subtypes.
title: Common variants in breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: This variant had stronger associations with luminal A-like disease compared to TN disease.
title: Common variants in breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: This variant had stronger evidence of association with risk of luminal A-like disease compared to TN disease, reflecting its differential impact on breast cancer subtypes.
title: Common variants in breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: This intronic variant in the hexokinase 1 (HK1) region on chromosome 10 showed a significant association with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) as well as with red blood cell-related traits, specifically linking these clinical traits with average SpO2. It reached genome-wide significance for minimal and average SpO2 in previous studies.
title: Leveraging pleiotropy to discover and interpret GWAS results for sleep-associated traits

finding: The SNP rs1555839 was previously associated with rapid automatized naming and yielded a significant signal in the current analysis, showing association with spelling (p=3.33 × 10−4). This association indicates its relevance in the context of reading and language-related skills.
title: Genome-wide association analyses of individual differences in quantitatively assessed reading- and language-related skills in up to 34,000 people

finding: The SNP rs11010099 was mentioned in relation to its opposing effects on cancer properties, specifically its differential regulation of Wnt/beta-Catenin/Notch signaling pathways in breast and colon cancers. The findings suggested that this SNP could inform therapeutic approaches targeting cancer stem cells.
title: Identification and Pharmacological Targeting of Treatment-Resistant, Stem-like Breast Cancer Cells for Combination Therapy

finding: In the study by Rijken et al. (2019), the SNP rs11010103 was associated with increased mortality among carriers of SDHB pathogenic variants. This finding suggested a significant impact of this SNP on the clinical outcomes specifically in individuals affected by familial paraganglioma neuroendocrine tumors.
title: A chemical screen for suppressors of dioxygenase inhibition in a yeast model of familial paraganglioma

finding: The rs10997355 SNP, identified as an intron variant in the CTNNA3 gene, was found to have a significant association with major depressive disorder (MDD) using the Nearest-neighbor Projected-Distance Regression (NPDR) technique. This SNP was involved in an analysis of eQTLs influencing the expression of the SCAI gene, a known regulator of cell migration and the cell cycle. Previous studies indicated a modest cis-eQTL effect for rs10997355 in this dataset and an interaction with maternal cytomegalovirus (CMV) status, suggesting a potential gene-environment interaction impacting mood disorders.
title: Nearest-neighbor Projected-Distance Regression (NPDR) for detecting network interactions with adjustments for multiple tests and confounding

finding: This SNP was associated with the tract connecting the left and right precuneus, showing a z-score of -5.58.
title: Genetic architecture of the white matter connectome of the human brain

finding: The SNP rs11101618 was associated with the cancer hub genes identified in the NECARE analysis. The context of the finding related to its enrichment in gene interaction perturbations in cancer, highlighting its potential significance in cancer prognosis across 32 types of cancers.
title: Network-based cancer gene relationship prediction method reveals perturbations in the cancer gene network

finding: This SNP also contributed to the regulation of autophagy initiation mechanisms, making it a significant finding within PD-related gene pathways.
title: Establishing gene regulatory networks from Parkinson’s disease risk loci

finding: The SNP rs1680636 was associated with coronary artery disease (CAD) and exclusively interacted with CXCL12 in a 200-kb loop. Significant associations suggested its role in cardiac remodeling genes in heart disease context.
title: Dissecting Regulatory Non-Coding Heart Disease GWAS Loci with High-Resolution 3D Chromatin Interactions Reveals Causal Genes with Pathophysiological Relevance to Heart Failure

finding: The SNP rs61839660, located within the CaRE4 enhancer, was found to reduce the risk of developing Type 1 diabetes (T1D) with an Odds Ratio of 0.62 and a p value of 2.8 x 10^-39. However, it was also associated with an increased risk of developing Crohn's Disease. This SNP's influence mimicked the effect of a regulatory enhancer perturbation in activated conventional T cells (Tconvs), albeit with a more modest impact on IL-2ra expression.
title: Non-coding sequence variation reveals fragility within interleukin 2 feedback circuitry and shapes autoimmune disease risk

finding: Shimaoka et al. (2019) identified this SNP in relation to connexins and integrins in exosomes, contributing to the understanding of intercellular communication mechanisms in cancer, which included implications for colorectal cancer progression.
title: Deciphering stiffness-driven changes in colorectal cancer by proteomics

finding: The SNP rs45596840 in miR-4482 demonstrated significant association with RA with a p-value of 6.6×10^-3.
title: MicroRNA variants and HLA-miRNA interactions are novel rheumatoid arthritis susceptibility factors

finding: The SNP rs10748818 was associated with the NFKB2 locus, where significant associations were found with rare coding variants impacting the risk for PD after stringent correction.
title: Expanding Parkinson’s disease genetics: novel risk loci, genomic context, causal insights and heritable risk

finding: The rs41290536 variant caused a shortening of the 3' UTR of the BLOC1S2 gene by replacing a canonical PAS with a non-canonical one. This variant was in complete LD with two other variants previously associated with squamous cell lung carcinoma.
title: The genetic determinants of the relative expression of alternative 3’UTR isoforms in human

finding: The SNP rs7903146 was classified as a shared signal at the TCF7L2 locus, with TOA scores of 0.31 for islet and 0.37 for adipose, indicating distinct contributions to T2D risk in both tissues.
title: A multi-omic integrative scheme characterizes tissues of action at loci associated with type 2 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs11257655 at the CDC123-CAMK1D locus was designated as an islet signal with significant colocalization with an eQTL for CAMK1D in human islets.
title: A multi-omic integrative scheme characterizes tissues of action at loci associated with type 2 diabetes

finding: This SNP was associated with the <italic>BICC1</italic> gene, which plays a significant role in canonical Wnt signaling. It was embedded in a constitutive nucleosome-depleted region adjacent to active enhancer chromatin, suggesting its involvement in regulating BMD risk. Significant eQTL data indicated it likely contributes to inherited osteoporosis risk.
title: Prioritization of osteoporosis-associated GWAS SNPs using epigenomics and transcriptomics

finding: This SNP was identified as critical for <italic>BICC1</italic> expression, involved in Wnt signaling. It was found in strong enhancer chromatin and was linked to positive effect sizes in eQTL studies, reinforcing its role in BMD regulation.
title: Prioritization of osteoporosis-associated GWAS SNPs using epigenomics and transcriptomics

finding: Like rs1896245, this SNP was included in the <italic>BICC1</italic> Tier-1 SNPs, associated with the regulation of bone mineral density through enhancer interactions. Its location within transcriptionally active chromatin positions it as a key regulatory element.
title: Prioritization of osteoporosis-associated GWAS SNPs using epigenomics and transcriptomics

finding: This SNP is part of the <italic>BICC1</italic> regulatory cluster and was embedded in enhancer chromatin. Its association with eQTLs in skeletal muscle suggests a role in inherited osteoporosis.
title: Prioritization of osteoporosis-associated GWAS SNPs using epigenomics and transcriptomics

finding: This SNP was part of the established <italic>BICC1</italic> regulatory SNPs and is involved in transcription regulatory processes, contributing to bone density variation as indicated by its eQTL data.
title: Prioritization of osteoporosis-associated GWAS SNPs using epigenomics and transcriptomics

finding: Similar to others in the <italic>BICC1</italic> gene cluster, this SNP was linked to bone mineral density through regulatory chromatin interactions, thus supporting its role in osteoporosis risk.
title: Prioritization of osteoporosis-associated GWAS SNPs using epigenomics and transcriptomics

finding: Identified within the <italic>BICC1</italic> cluster, this SNP's association with chromatin states aligns with its role as a regulatory element influencing bone health.
title: Prioritization of osteoporosis-associated GWAS SNPs using epigenomics and transcriptomics

finding: The SNP rs10823108 in SIRT1 was found to be associated with genetic susceptibility to diabetic nephropathy. This association was identified through studies analyzing the impact of SIRT1 on glucose metabolism and insulin signaling. The finding was considered original as it contributed significantly to understanding genetic factors influencing diabetic complications.
title: A natural genetic variation screen identifies insulin signaling, neuronal communication, and innate immunity as modifiers of hyperglycemia in the absence of Sirt1

finding: The rs2506030 SNP was identified as an enhancer polymorphism linked to HSCR, where the G allele was described as the risk allele. Previous research indicated that specific haplotypes could significantly affect RET signaling, and in this study, it was crucial in categorizing cell line phenotypes to understand RET variant implications.
title: Variability in proliferative and migratory defects in Hirschsprung disease-associated RET pathogenic variants

finding: The rs7069590 SNP was classified as an HSCR-associated enhancer polymorphism with the T allele as the risk allele. The importance of this SNP lay in its role in categorizing haplotypes that influenced RET expression levels in the context of Hirschsprung disease.
title: Variability in proliferative and migratory defects in Hirschsprung disease-associated RET pathogenic variants

finding: The rs2435357 SNP was also studied as an enhancer polymorphism associated with HSCR. Similar to the other SNPs, the T allele was reported as the risk allele, playing a role in distinguishing RET susceptibility and aiding in the functional assessment of RET variants in the study.
title: Variability in proliferative and migratory defects in Hirschsprung disease-associated RET pathogenic variants

finding: The rs17158558 SNP was associated with Hirschsprung disease, as indicated by a VDA score of 0.7, suggesting a reputable connection through curated sources.
title: Comprehensive assessment of Indian variations in the druggable kinome landscape highlights distinct insights at the sequence, structure and pharmacogenomic stratum

finding: SNP rs2506030 was identified as one of the SNPs with differential enhancer activity. Its deletion in enhancer RET-7 resulted in significant loss of RET expression, confirming its role as a risk variant associated with Hirschsprung disease.
title: A multi-enhancer RET regulatory code is disrupted in Hirschsprung disease

finding: SNP rs7069590 demonstrated differential enhancer activity. In the deletion of enhancer RET-5.5, significant loss of RET expression was observed, highlighting its contribution to HSCR risk.
title: A multi-enhancer RET regulatory code is disrupted in Hirschsprung disease

finding: This SNP was associated with enhancer RET+3 and showed significant enhancer activity. Its deletion resulted in substantial reduction of RET expression, confirming its involvement in Hirschsprung disease.
title: A multi-enhancer RET regulatory code is disrupted in Hirschsprung disease

finding: The functional polymorphism rs11572080 in the CYP2C8 gene was analyzed with regard to colorectal cancer risk and found to be associated, indicating its relevance in cancer genetics.
title: Identification of hub genes and key pathways in pediatric Crohn’s disease using next generation sequencing and bioinformatics analysis

finding: Polymorphisms rs7093069 in IL-2RA and related SNPs were analyzed in adolescents with autoimmune thyroid diseases, hinting at broader implications in autoimmune conditions including inflammatory bowel diseases.
title: Identification of hub genes and key pathways in pediatric Crohn’s disease using next generation sequencing and bioinformatics analysis

finding: The T allele of TCF7L2 rs7903146 was found to be associated with decreased glucose tolerance after bed rest in healthy older adults, highlighting its relevance to metabolic health.
title: High exposure variance enables candidate biomarker detection in a small EWAS of methylmercury-exposed Peruvian adults
